												Supreme Commander isn't your usual cup of strategy game. It is more like the big hairy uncle of yours that think bare knuckle boxing teaches character. Supreme Commander takes everything you'll find it in your standard RTS and supersizes it. From the very first mission onwards you will be overcome with a strange new feeling as you get thrown into a game with an almost unprecedented scale. The maps are not simply bigger than what you are used to, they blow everything previous to oblivion and the maps are not where this massive scale stops. Not only do you control massive armies and giant bases with humongous defensive networks but the units and buildings themselves are beyond what you usually find in an RTS game. Giant robots, massive spaceships and artillery pieces that can throw shells from Monday to Friday. If this game was a car I'd say the owner was compensating for something. Various design mechanics are hard at work to keep it all from overwhelming you. The zoom function allows to you go right down to group level and all the way out to where you can see the entire map. Instead of having to build new tech every so often everything has an upgrade function allowing old factories to produce the latest and greatest in units, your defenses to stay effective and your resource gathers to not fall behind. The entire game and the buildup of power and technology that happens throughout a game is a very fluid process and only rarely do you find yourself having nothing to do.Something that shouldn't be ignored either is that Supreme Commander, despite it's scale and the massive amount of units that can appear in a game manages to not only run really well, it also looks good.Supreme Commander is an RTS on steroids. It's like nothing we've seen for a very long time and it does everything it tries so very well.

Get both!One of the greatest RTS games of all time.If you like commanding hundreds of sea, air, and land units please read on.Don't let the low hours on Steam trick you. Eight of my friends and I bought this game on CD years ago. We would reoutinely play 6 to 8 co-op or multiplayer (free for all) games on LAN before the Internet speeds really got fast. Each side can have hundreds of units (we've had 8 sides in one large battle).3. Mouse zoom in/out. I can't explain in words the many ways this feature is plain useful and should be the standard in RTS games. You can zoom into a low level (one unit) and out to see the entire map and units are then represented as particular icons (easily identifiable). You can issue any command or select any unit from low to high level zooms. It's plain awesome.4. True faction faction and unit differences. Big difference between tier 1, 2, 3, and experiental units.5. Interesting upgrade paths for commander with multiple paths (Builder, fighter, stealth, etc).6. Short cut keys to do same thing as mouse.7. Four factions that look, feel, and really behave different.8. True land, sea (above and below), and air units.9. Transports (air or sea) with fantastic transport queueing/ferry options.10. Graphics look great, even for an old game.11. Posted: July 28, 2014
												I have always loved and enjoyed playing real-time strategy games, and Supreme Commander satisfied my hunger pretty well.If you like real-time strategy, alien/futuristic themes, and challenging gameplay, you will enjoy this game.The aesthetics are very good, with nice special effects for the different weapons and units. There are 3 factions, each with a fairly large pool of different units to choose from (land, air, and water). The music and sound is decent.The controls are typical of an RTS-game - lots of hotkeying and keystrokes if you are familiar with this type of gameplay. The learning curve is moderate to challenging - especially if you are unfamiliar with the RTS genre. The tutorials are very helpful and recommended if you want to get a quick grasp of the game. There are a number of difficulty settings when playing agains the AI (I always start of with a skirmish against the AI whenever I first try a new RTS).There are two types of resources, energy and mass, and managing/balancing your upkeep of both is critical to being successful in this game. You can actually hit a standstill if you try to build/produce too many things at once and run out of resources. I still have not been able to find a way to cancel/delete buildings in progress, however, you are able to pass construction to free up resources.The feedback in the game is very good - health bars over each unit, a +/- number indicating how much of either resource you are gaining/losing per second (you can switch this with an efficiency %). There are tabs for each research level when you are trying to build structures or train units. There isn't much detail on each unit type (I am used to seeing things like attack damage, defense, etc). From what I've seen, you are only provided with the unit/building health, type (ex: attack submarine, spy plane), and amount of time to train/build.The story is pretty interesting, there is a nice cutscene in the beginning of the game that paints the setting for you. You have a commander unit who can attack, build, and reclaim resources. This unit must survive, and you lose if he is defeated. To give a quick boost to resources, you can use your commander (or any engineer/construction units) to reclaim/absorb materials from things like buildings, forests, and destroyed structures/units. The commander unit can also upgrade his components (chest piece, left/right arm piece, back). For example, you can either give the commander a resource boosting arm (for when you use him to relaim material) or a weapons boost on his left arm (you can remove pieces if you wish; upgrading your commander is very expensive and usually done later in the game).Gameplay is similar to many RTS-games I've played like Red Alert and Tiberian Sun series - there is a faction with cloaked units (radar sensor building to counter). A lot of the battles are decided by rock-paper-scissors mechanics (bombers to destroy buildings and/or slow-moving artillery, fighters to destroy bombers, anti-air to destroy both, tanks to destroy gun emplacements, etc). I do like the versatility of your commander - you can upgrade him to be more of a combat specialist or a building expert.Overall, I think you should give this game a try if you are interested in the theme or RTS-genre in general, however, the sequel is out, and for a cheaper price too. That being said, I would still give this game a playthrough - especially if you are an RTS-buff/junkie.Recommend!

Posted: January 19
												If you liked Total Annihilation, you will like this one. It's more or less the same game, but it has 3 factions which are actually different from each other. The campaign spans 6 missions per faction on ever expanding battlefields. This makes the missions fluid and you have to adapt to new situations on the fly.Apart from that it's still "build mass extractors and energy generators to supply your constant building of army units". Yes, this game is not about micro, but macro management. Your units don't cost "money" per se, but each building and each unit cost a certain amount of resources/second. If you're spending more than you're generating production slows down considerably. Different builder units and production facilities also have different outputs. To build an army quickly you will need to use builders to speed up production. It's a big old turtle and siege game. Whether you use artillery supported by main battle tanks, anti aircraft units and mobile shield batteries or different navy ships or a combination of bombers with fighter escorts and perhaps some gunship strafing runs, it all comes down to who can cripple the enemies economy better. Since there are no finite resources a skirmish can practically go on forever and end in a stalemate.Luckily there are also super units and long range nuclear and artillery gun emplacements to potentially kill the enemy. After all, all it takes to win is to kill the enemy commander, which can happen almost instantaneously in the late game. That's also why rushing in this game isn't very effective. The command unit will take care of most Tier 1 units pretty quickly, unless you have a ♥♥♥♥ton of them.To be honest, unit control could be a bit more precise. Often your units will simply clump up and die one after another. It's a big grind fest. Especially naval and air units are problematic. Air units told to resupply will often just circle the resupply pads for ages, despite being "done". Naval units need too much space where none is available, so in a group of 10 ships it often happened that only 1 moved to the destination... Also unit information when selecting an actual unit and not just with mouseover would have been cool. All in all it's a neat little macro strategy fest though with clear rock, paper, scissors gameplay: Break base with artillery, protect artillery with tanks, protect all of them with anti air and add some shielding into the mix. Done.

												I can tell you one thing about this game, it's so time consuming you won't even realize the time is gone.But that's one of the problems though, is that the game can literally go on for 7 hours.It takes about 40 mins to build one of the Tier 3 things, and you either make like 50 engineers to work on it, or you wait an hour to get something built.The combat however, is fun. You can make a crap load of troops and just have a massive battle. It feels like a real war, and it isn't like AoE where you can only have about 200 troops total. Unit diversity is key here. Unlike AoE 3, you cannot win by having a massive spam of the same few units.  ( AoE 3: 50 Skirmishers, 50 Uhlans, 20 Falconets and the rest musketeers )This does make early combat VERY boring though, as several base turrets will mow down hundreds of your troops, which take about 7 seconds each.There's LAND, AIR, and NAVAL combat, all in one. ( Some maps don't have water )The actual involvement in combat is very little though, there isn't much to do, formations don't really matter, and it's hard to get a proper battle formation, because of the way the formations work. There aren't any abilities or anything either, and you can't really do much micro-ing, because everyone can just turn around and shoot while running, so there isn't really any point. Units die extremely quick anyways, so having a small army is meaningless unless they're high tier.The 3 factions in the game don't really add any diversity whatsoever.I think it's to balance the game, but it kinda makes it dull. The only difference is the way the look.The game is buggy on every OS that isn't Windows XP, so make sure you use a service pack or something.There's a LOT of building required in this game. You have to probably build bases that are 1/10th of the map (By the Tier 3) I feel like there's too much focused on construction. I think I'm just building stuff 80% of the time.I can't find anyone to play multiplayer with, but when I look at it there were some pretty cool things. You can switch sides, and ally with people and stuff, just like AoE 2. You can also share resources if needed.Overall, I think it's a worth while game, but only for people who really want to play strategy, otherwise, it can be hard to get into.

												Supreme Commander is one of the granddaddy Real Time Strategy games from the era of Starcraft 1 and the Command & Conquer games. Like its predecessor Total Annihilation, Supreme Commander is all about huge battlefields and hordes of units running around. No need to worry about building pylons or supply depots to increase your build limit, just mass produce your favorite units from your half dozen factories and overrun your enemies.According to the game’s opening cinematic, the Earth Empire spread out over the galaxy and eventually fractured into 3 factions. The UEF is the “old guard” faction that is probably closest to modern day United States. The Cybran Nation / Symbionts were born from a fusion of human brains with computers to create enhanced artificial intelligence. And the final faction Aeon Illuminate is kind of an enlightened (or cultish) group who follow an alien religion called The Way (even though the aliens themselves were wiped out long ago). Each faction has their own single player campaign to conquer the galaxy, and even though they cross over each other, they have mutually exclusive endings like Command & Conquer. They don’t all form a single story, like Starcraft. At first glance, Supreme Commander seems to be built around the ACU (Armored Command Unit) which is a giant human shaped robot that strides across the battlefield blasting enemies and building structures. In reality though, the ACU is more like a mobile command center. Other than being a really tough builder unit, the ACU doesn’t have too much going for it. It can’t build the more advanced structures and it’s not such a great fighter. However, if you lose the ACU, you lose the game. If you’ve played the Command & Conquer games, you should be pretty comfortable starting up with Supreme Commander. For one thing, fixed defensive buildings (turrets) are extremely hard to kill, so turtling in is a really effective tactic in the single player campaign.If you’re used to playing real time strategy games, Supreme Commander’s build system may seem counter-intuitive. You don’t need to have the money up front to buy units or buildings since everything is paid for “over time.” As soon as you start building something, the mass supply (your money) starts being drained a certain amount per second. If you run out of mass, the build pauses, but since your mass is also gained over time (not in little clusters like Starcraft), the actual effect is that your build just gets slowed down (as soon as your mass goes up +1, it gets drained for the building). This means you can start building your entire base at the start of every level, but you should probably let some of the buildings finish first, like power plants and mass extractors (money makers). It sounds weird when I try to explain it, but it makes sense when you play.Probably the biggest difference between Supreme Commander and a lot of other real time strategy games though, is the size of the level maps. The maps are so large that you need to use your mouse scroll wheel to constantly zoom in and out at different locations to see what’s going on. There’s no mini-map in the corner of your screen. The “tech levels” for Supreme Commander are also unlike many other real time strategy games. Your engineer (builder unit) can only build structures up to its current level, and the engineer cannot be upgraded. For example, a level 1 engineer can only build level 1 buildings. If you want to build level 3 buildings, you need to build a level 3 engineer. Every production building also upgrades tech levels independently. So if you have 2 land factories and one of them is level 2, only that factory can create level 2 buildings until you upgrade the second land factory. Honestly it seems like a waste of time to me, especially if you like to build large numbers of factories at once to really pump out the units.Pros:+Huge maps with room for massive battles between armies of units. The Air, Land, and Sea are your battlefield, and along with the expansive area, there’s a huge variety of units to choose from. There is a unit cap, but it doesn’t seem to be explicitly stated anywhere. If you just set all your factories to autobuild units, you’ll reach the cap eventually.+Artillery! Long range bombardment is probably my favorite weapon in real time strategy games. You can have mobile missile launchers and even fixed artillery launcher buildings pounding your enemies. There are also strategic missile launchers (nukes) but the enemy can build strategic missile defense structures that automatically counter your nukes, so I don’t really see the point.+The game is quite long, so if you are enjoying yourself, you can kill over 30 hours just playing through the 3 single player campaigns. There only seem to be 6 levels each, but they’re not straightforward “kill everything” missions. They usually expand the map several times each level (complete an objective, boom the map doubles in size and you’re now surrounded). Fortunately, Supreme Commander has a “speed up time” option that increases the rate the game plays. You can play at up to 10x normal speed, but you should really only do this if you’re waiting for your buildings/units to finish construction.Cons:-The game can be hard to get used to, especially the formations of troops when you have a large army. The naval units especially take multiple commands to get them to form up how you want them. The game’s tutorial is not in an obvious place in the main menu. It really should have been either part of the “campaign menu” or right above “campaign” at the start. Instead, it’s kind of in the middle of options. -Since you’re constantly zoomed out on the battlefield to get an overview of the map, you really don’t get to see much in the way of graphics. You mostly just see dots firing more dots at enemy dots. Granted, the game is pretty old so you shouldn’t be expecting top notch graphics as the main draw.Overall, the game is fun for people who enjoy real time strategy games. There are no steam achievements, so if you just want to see the story you can set the game to easy and slog your way through. Yes, even on easy mode it will take quite a while to beat the game because of just how massive the levels are. Remember to build up your base defenses, and the computer will crack its head open on your turrets.

												What can I say?  I love Total Annihilation, Planetary Annihilation is an abomination, and I wanted a TA-like RTS.  This is how you do it, a gem by Gas Powered Games and THQ (now replaced with Nordic, who moved the game to Steamworks servers).  It's got a great artstyle, three exceptional campaigns with intriguing and well-executed stories, and a small but dedicated and polite online community.There's literally nothing I can say against this game.  Total Annihilation, Age of Empires II, and Red Alert II remain my all-time favorite RTS games, but this game has completely replaced TA on that list.  It crushed my nostalgic love for the game with full 3D visuals and fantastic gameplay, an accomplishment that should never be overlooked.Whereas most RTS's fall apart in the singleplayer department, this game's campaigns stand the test of time with quality writing and great missions.  While some lack proper multiplayer-ing, this game's netcode gets the job done well, now under the eternal watch of Gaben and the Steamworks serverlistin the clouds.  It's also very compatible with modern hardware and runs well on a variety of systems.  There's plenty of lasting value with three campaigns and factions who all play differently from each other and an active multiplayer scene.I seriously can't recommend this game enough, it's one of the best RTS's I've ever had the pleasure of trying. 												Even though I gave this game a thumbs up in my original review, now that I've played Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance, I realize that there is absolutely no reason to play Supreme Commander 1.  Forged Alliance is better in every respect and it's a stand-alone expansion, so just play that.-----ORIGINAL REVIEW-----------------------------------------------------------------------I would recommend playing Supreme Commander - at the end of the day it's a really fun game, and it has its incredible moments.  However, this game did not live up to its legendary reputation for me.  Granted, I don't like playing RTS multiplayer because I don't find it fun spending hours optimizing every mouse click, so this is based on my experience with singleplayer.This game puzzles me because some aspects are mind-blowingly cool, and others are absolutely moronic.  Examples of the mind-blowingly cool stuff:- Battleships that grow legs and walk on land AKA the most radical amphibian assaults you can imagine.- Giant artillery guns that can fire on enemy bases continents away.- An incredibly deep economy based on "Mass" which is used to produce things, and "Energy" which is consumed while you produce things.- Experimental units AKA GIANT LASER SPIDER ROBOTS WTF!!!- Tactical nuclear missle launches....and the list goes on.  But then you get to the moronic crap:- Units and Buildings share a unit limit - if you build too many units, you can't build anymore buildings.  HUH?!?!?!?- Tutorial is basically "Welcome to the tutorial!  Here is a button that opens the in-game 20-page manual.  Thanks for playing the tutorial!"- Units have no sense of self-preservation and make no attempts to escape enemy fire - if a unit cannot fire back at the attacking enemy, it will just sit there like an idiot and let itself die.- No unit formations (that's kind of basic for an RTS).and also (and this is absolutely infurianting), all your land units act like distracted people at a stoplight.  When you give them a move order, the ones at the front will wait a second, then start moving, and the remaining units will not move until the ones in front of them have moved.  Imagine giving a square formation of tanks an order to move into an enemy base - that nice tight formation will spread itself out into vulnerable line, and instead of a wall of firepower overwhelming the enemy, your tanks will end up entering the enemy base one at a time politely letting the enemy defenses individually pick them off.This is unacceptable.  I don't know if it's intentional, or if there's some way to prevent this I don't know about - but in a game that's all about large scale conflict, it's unacceptable to give a large group of units a move order and end up with some of them still at your base waiting for their turn to move while the front of the column is already at the enemy base getting killed because they have no back up.But like I said, at the end of the day, it was fun to play and the cool moments this game provides are worth it.  I just don't think this is the RTS masterpiece that everyone claims it is.

Posted: October 28, 2015
												I don't recommend this game unless you really enjoy turtling.  It has good ideas, but they are poorly implemented.  Painfully slow build times on units and structures, mass fabricators destroying any need to control the map and the resources scattered across it, and incredibly powerful defenses turn this into a painful slog.  The ability to control and upgrade the commander who represents you in the game is neat at first, but they quickly become the big can which sits in the middle of its defense riddled, mass fabricator clogged base and never leaves.  Because if the commander does leave, it runs a good chance of dying and losing the match.What the game offers:  The BasicsYou play as a commander aligned with one of three factions which can build basic structures.  The factories let you get fabricators which build even better structures.  Upgrade the factories to get better fabricators for better structures and units.  You also need to balance production with your resource income, so make sure you're building mass pumps, power generators, and mass fabricators to meet your base's growing needs. When it comes to crushing the opposition, you are given many options, and your three starting ones are land units, naval units, and air units.  At higher fabricator tiers, you can get long range artillery, stealth, experimental units, and strategic missle launchers (nukes).  Of course, all of this can be countered easily at lower cost by defenses.  In order to defeat an enemy, you need to either catch their commander while it's exposed or have an overwhelming advantage to push through their defenses.Mass pumps provide the most mass at the lowest energy cost, but they can only be built atop mass deposits scattered across the map.  Ideally, the game would become a battle to control and defend mass pumps for a production edge over the opponent.  Sadly, mass fabricators destroy this by allowing a player to acquire all of the mass they will ever need from the comfort and safety of their own base, often at a faster pace and at less expense.The factions are almost entirely aesthetics, with their only major differences being what experimental units they can build.  They all have the same unit classes and structures which do the same jobs.  There are small bits of fluff like "Aeon bomber does damage over (a very short) time, cybran bomber does slightly less damage over a slightly larger area, and UEF is a typical bomber with a large explosion and good damage."  But ultimately the differences are minimal.Three CampaignsThe story is decent in each of the three races' campaigns, but the basics makes them a slow mess.  Even the first map in the campaign takes at least forty minutes to finish simply because of how long it takes to build everything and amass enough firepower to win.  And it only goes down hill from there.  Expect one to two hours for each campaign map.Skirmishes with AI'sThese often take just as long as the campaign maps, although tech rushing (spending all of your resources on obtaining max tech units and structures as quickly as possible) can end an AI opponent quickly.  It is impossible to beat the AI at spamming mass fabricators, so be prepared for a long slog if the battle isn't ended quickly.  The AI skirmishes also seem to be buggy and occasionally crash to desktop for me, so beware.MultiplayerAs other reviews have stated, look at Forged Alliances if you want an active online community.  I haven't tried it, but from what I have read online, expect cheese.This game may be worth buying on sale.  If you're really liking some of these ideas, I'd recommend Planetary Annihilation when it is on sale instead if you don't mind its lack of a story filled campaign.  It uses a large number of the same ideas in Supreme Commander, but is a better tuned experience overall.

												Back when i got this game in a box from target, it introduced me to the gnere of RTS. With its big battles and complex strategy, i thought of this game as the standard of all RTS games. After trying other RTS games like Command and conquor and Empire Earth, i realised how exceptionaly amazing this game really is.Supreme Commander lets you make and take control of your own army while trying to destroy someone elses like all RTSs. But while most RTSs let you control a few units to make armies, this game lets you use hundreds of them, giving rise to situatons of "how do i defend agaisnt their 500 bombers while not losing my factories?" or "Wheres the best place to attack with my 700 gunships and what to do with these nukes?" and minutes later "HOW DID THAT NOT WORK?" (NOTE: do not try to use nukes in combination with gunships, gunships are not nuke-proof) The game has a resource system based on 2 resources that are required for everything. Every little bot you build for your armies of mass destruction will cost mass and energy to build, bot of which are easy to obtain and require little maintenance to keep up with your production unless your opponet destroys them. The game also has 4 tiers of units from the basic light tanks of tier 1 to the experimental lazer eyed and nozed colossal sized bots of tier 4 ( also called the experimental tier)I thought the game was better from the box than from steam as some of the units are borrowed from Forged Alliance here. (Forged Alliance is better than the original Supreme Commander and totaly worth the 5 extra dollers in the gold edition) Not that the units are bad, but the gameplay changes when one faction has suicidal bombers. The game also tends to crash a bit when you get 8000 unit battles going but i dont know any computers that can handle that many units and their animated shells and rounds too.If your getting this game for the campaign, just a warning, the plot isnt the best ive seen and the AI is a bit annoying reminding you to complete your objectives every few minutes. 												Gameplay- SUPREME COMMANDER is an amazing game which startles with its ease of execution of global conflict and easy to get into user interface while still offering a challenging thought provoking ai to go up against. At first i thought i was going to end up with a very chugging along slow grand scale war situation like the old gargantuan wargame from the early 1990s UMS (UNIVERSAL MILITARY SIMULATOR). Instead i found something that played with the massive variety of units of TOTAL ANNIHILATION and depth of such old time classics like BATTLE ISLE and THE PERFECT GENERAL done in real time with stunning movie like battle visuals. It was a eerie scary sight to see a huge enemy frigate when destroyed actually roll over on its side and sink like something out of a old time war reel. Plenty of time will be spent on building bases and units but you are free to acttack or do recon missions etc at any time. Building bases is alot of fun with plenty of upgrades which one has to invest heavy resources of mass and or energy to make possible. Graphics- Very immersive with plenty of visual detail when it comes to things like air units going into and dive and crashing with 3d depth not to mention the consequences as the explosion from the crash can damage any nearby structures and or units. Everything is done in layers of depth and mass so all that wreckage on the field will actually get in your way the cool thing is you can get it out of your way by salvaging as resources or in the case of one of your own buildings being wrecked you can rebuild the same building over the wrecked one taking half the time it normally would to build it. There are plenty of video popups of the other commanders friendly and enemy reminding you your not alone on the battlefield and you have objectives to complete. The enemy on the other hand is sending plenty of threats and taunts your way which enrich the war mood of battles. Sound- Excellent use of sfx making everything seem like you on another world in some futuristic time with sci-fi weapons designed to deliever devastation to your enemies and your own units if your too close when they explode in a raging fire storm of nuclear death. Sum Total- A must buy sci-fi wargame which really delievers. If you have not played it yet now is the time with the beefy computer systems of today and the past year that can easily handle its beefy overhead. Thank you Chris Taylor and company for the fantastic satisfying work :D

												If you've played Total Annihilation, you'll know the basics of how this game works already. And yet, this spiritual successor improves upon its unique RTS formula in almost every way possible. The price was worth it just for the single player campaigns, and I haven't even touched multiplayer yet.There's a simple hierarchy of 4 tiers and gives you so many options in combat. Unlimited resources (in a manner of speaking) lets you do more than other RTS games would. Even though Starcraft 1 and 2 are my favourite RTS games ever, this game is very refreshing in comparison with the freedom you have. You can turtle effectively with an impenetrable base and use long range nuclear missiles or artillery battery to destroy your opponent. You can send a swarm of 200 gunships to take them out. Or use an army of Tier 3 siege bots and AA bots. And you can use aircraft, land units and naval units. Then there's the unique, experimental units which take a lot of effort to build but are very fun to watch wrecking things. And let's not forget the ability to zoom out or in to almost any degree you feel like.The main campaigns are good and fun, even though the pacing could be a little better. I'd like to use the tier 3 siege bots, battleships and gunships a bit earlier. And you don't get to use the experimental units until halfway through the last mission- which is a little disappointing.There are only a few things I would say are bad about the game. Compared to Starcraft, it feels a lot slower. You need air transport to get your engineers anywhere other than your main base in an acceptable time fashion. Queing orders when selecting multiple units sometimes results in them repeating builds that have already been done, wasting precious time. The campaign also has an annoying unit limit that applies to buildings as well, and there's no quick way to delete units if need be. A simple "delete" command would have been nice. Commanding armies has advanced controls but the units themselves still bump into each other and not attack as a clumped group (like Starcraft 2 handles very well). Projectiles operate in an immersive way, with bullets or missiles homing or not depending on the unit, but some units are nearly impossible to kill efficiently without transporting engineers and building defenses (tier 3 air superiority, ugh).The graphics are very impressive considering how old the game is, and I still like zooming in to inspect all the high tech lights and power networks I construct.My life for the Aeon Illuminate!

												If you were a fan of the classic robot armada strategy Total Annihilation you will be right at home with Supreme Commander.With land, Air and Sea battles, constant attacks, limited resources and vast battle grounds there is plenty of warfare to be had. At times the pace feels slow, particularly when setting up your initial base on a large map, however, when you find yourself being hammered by endless hordes of your opponents forces, almost in a panic trying to grind out a force good enough to repel the attacks, all the while desperately defending your resource production line, you will at times miss the slower pace of the base building phase.The story is somewhat shallow and is really just a hook to guide you from world to world, ultimately leading to that all important end-game battle, but you didn’t come here for the story, did you? Multiplayer is the most fun aspect of this game. It is even more enjoyable when you play locally and can hear your opponent scream and curse you when you expertly execute a fast air attack, taking out metal production and temporary shutting down his unit production. The matches can be long arduous events and occasionally the victor might be determined by someone giving in, rather than a skilful victory, but still there is much fun to be had, just choose the map according to the intended game time.With all that said Supreme commander is a lot of fun and well worth your invested time and energy.

												BTW: hundreds of hours on pre-steam.So, you're looking for an RTS to play, and this one has popped up in the list.You've played a fair few RTS games, and certainly most of the mainstream ones.This one claims to be different, better give it a look.Now, there are reviews that have gone into far more detail than I'm going to offer you, but what I will say is very important.There are a few games where economies are progressive for units - that is, the resources you have amassed drain away as the unit builds. Now, you'd think this method would be used more wouldn't you? Well, it's hard to balance properly - you've got 3 unit factories building units, and then you run out, so all of them stall, wasting more time than if you had built one at a time right.What Supreme Commander does is sort out those balance issues, and expand on the progressive economy aspect.Units, buildings, upgrades, super weapon use... all of these things are linked into the economy almost 100%, with time being the only real drain on that percentage (super weapons take a proportionate amount of time to build etc).Building thirty different buildings including factories, defences and superweapons as well as running 12 different factories and existing artillery/superweapons and out of resources? Simple! Pause production on a few of the factories and some of the superweapons production.Not enough? Stop the artillery from firing, maybe even turn off some shield generators or resource converters.Sounds simple, but it's on such a large scale that it feels like running a proper future war economy.Now, maybe you've decided that you REALLY need to get some of those buildings built. Ok then, convert dead units into resources. Not enough? Convert functional units into resources, or maybe one of the buildings you don't really need?Haven't got the time to convert things into resources? Ok then, build your buildings over the destroyed remains of the same kind, that'll cut the time and resource cost by up to half!Or hell, you could go full city planning mode and arrange your resource-consuming buildings next to your resource-producing buildings.Why do that? "Does the electricity not have to go as far, so therefore it's more efficient?" you might smirk and say, but yes actually.Building like this puts in place what are basically powerlines between the buildings. This synergistic effect is incredibly noticeable almost immediately - a building produces 20 of a resource, or produces 20 of a resource and reduces the cost of the same in another building by 1%, and you can fit 20 along the sides of the building?This actually adds another element of risk though, big resource producers take a lot of synergised buildings with them, and those that survive take pretty hefty damage, which is what you'd expect - energy substation just got blown up, it's going to take some appliances down with it.And on top of all of the above, on top of all the super weapons you'd expect in an RTS, there is the commander unit.A core engineer unit isn't anything new to RTS games, but have the same potential for hilarity.Ever rushed an enemy with SCVs in StarCraft just to mess with their heads?What about rushing them with a veritable super weapon that unleashes a thermonuclear explosion when it dies?Not even Michael Baysplosion could hope to top that.
